displayed_text: Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: And then no pain. So, you’re the asymptomatic person Patient: Okay. Gotch ya. Doctor: and like uh, I got cancer, what, oh, perfect Provenge candidate. But you could get there again once like so he said can I get Provenge after Xofigo. Sure, if your pain was controlled. Even if your PSA wasn’t so low, having discomfort puts you in a different group. It just means your cancer is not behaving and having it go up on treatment is different than you not on anything and having it go up Patient: Okay. Doctor: and at this moment it’s not behaving. Patient: That’s why I’m always like at that time when I was low or no pain and that’s why he was thinking that’s what we… Doctor: Yeah, Yes, that would have been. Yeah. Patient: Okay. I understand that now. Doctor: So, like back then would have been or if we get you stable and kind of quiet and good we could always redo it, Patient: We can still. Okay. Okay. Doctor: Right. So, it’s not off the table forever. It’s just at this moment it’s not. Patient: At this moment, I understand that, okay.

Patient: Yeah. It depends. Sometimes I’m on gel pills and sometimes I’m on pills, pills. Doctor: So, those are the three medicines you take? Patient: Yes. Doctor: So the Eliquis, the Wellbutrin, and your calcium with vitamin D in it? Patient: Right. Doctor: Nothin’ new? Nothing new for bowels? Anything for pain? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. (Pause10sec) Patient: No. Doctor: Heart failure? Patient: No. Doctor: Any issues with – did you ever have a blood transfusion?

Family Member: Right. Doctor: Not with Dr. S_. Patient: I’m not going to get more radi— Doctor: So, you don’t necessarily need to keep seeing him. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. Just Patient: I think that’s probably his standard of care that he has to follow up, but if you’re following up - Doctor: Well, I would keep the appointment with him in January. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And, then, maybe after that I could see you in April and if it turns out in January, your PSA has, you know, gone - instead of continuing to go south, it’s gone north, or we may, we may need to switch treatments whatever, then I would, I would maybe see you sooner to discuss that. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, I, why don’t I - I’m going to make the appointment, I think, part of this appointment this January and, uh, I’m not sure if he’s doing the six-month injection, but, um, I’ll make an appointment for, it’s says April sixteenth. I’ll just make it April seventeenth which is a Tuesday. And, you don’t have to see him; you just see me.

Patient: Yeah. Well if you don’t mind, checking them out. Doctor: I’ll check with them. Patient: Yeah, because- Doctor: I know the guy at Cornell really well. Doing it is just an e-mail to say, hey, here’s my patient. How long would it take to get him on the trial? What’s the deal? And um- Patient: Okay. Doctor: He says we’re, we’ve got a waiting list out six months. Then you know we’re not going that way. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Terrific. Thank you. Doctor: So I’ll just let you know what the options are. Patient: Thank you. Appreciate it. Doctor: Alright?

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And your PSA will also be lower. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because part of the PSA going up with the testosterone was just turning on the production number. Patient: Of the testosterone? Doctor: Even if it didn’t make the cancer grow, or, or the cancer grew, whatever, just turning off the, the hormone might turn off the production. So, um, usually I see the PSA drop back down some. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So lots of things to throw at you. So what I’m going- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: My work is going to be to figure out what it would cost us to get on the Xtandi. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then this biopsy part of the trials, what, what’s required. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But when you’re on pills like that, experimental ones – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You don’t want to have some big surgery, be scheduled in the middle of it. Doesn’t make sense. Because you have to do one at a time. Patient: I got you. Doctor: Because it’s a big sur – I mean it’s a big one. (Cell phone rings) Patient: So let me ask you this here, doc. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Do people come out of that surgery? Doctor: Oh, yeah! They do! (Cell phone rings) Patient: Right. Doctor: But it’s a start. So, what does that tell us? It’s aggressive, but we know that about your cancer. But, if we don’t talk about surgery as an option, then we didn’t do right by you because you know that that’s a possibility. What’s the root of all that? Well, it’s your cancer not controlled. That’s always the root of all evil. Not your bones, but your lymph nodes are growing. So, in this –

Patient: Right. Doctor: Ahh to essentially sterilize the field that exposed to that… Patient: I’m sure it’s very pinpoint because my wife was over at the R ___. So, Doctor: It is, it is as precise as they can make it. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It’s done you know the modeling that they use, the 3D mapping… Patient: Sure. Doctor: …of the pelvis and targeting ah systems that they have is very accurate. As accurate as we can get with the current state-of-the-art, but… Patient: What would they be targeting? Doctor: They would be targeting the bed where the prostate was removed. Patient: Oh just around – around the urethra and th - Doctor: Correct, correct.

Patient: Fine. Doctor: Okay. Good to see you. Family Member: Thank you. Doctor: A ___ may want you to fill out something, so. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Yeah and where will I get the form for the appointment? Doctor: When you head out front, along that purple wall there there’s people there. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It should be pretty clean and nobody out there now. There might be somebody there and there may not be. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, let me see if A ___ needs to see you before you go. Patient: Okay. Do you have some paperclips? That’s fine. Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers::: strongly disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Some other race: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Some other race

displayed_text: Patient: I - at this point I think you all are taking pretty good care of me. So that means a lot to me and so, but I will touch base with him. Family Member: So this, I know it’s not cure. But you mentioned, you said remission a couple of times. What constitutes remission when you’re speaking of cancer? Doctor: Remission means that the cancer disappears completely. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Or partially. So the complete remission would mean that the PSA level goes to zero. Family Member: Is that something that could possibly happen in this case? Doctor: With the hormone therapy—yes. Family Member: With the hormone therapy—yes. Doctor: It happens frequently. Now it’s a bit misleading because it’s not truly zero. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: It’s below the limit of detection, so the laboratory for example is below zero point one milligrams per ml. Family Member: Uh hum.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So again, you’ve got the multiple sites of cancer in your bones, and you’ve got swollen glands down in your pelvis, don’t look like they’re from your cancer. Huh, let me see what I told you last time so that I am consistent. Okay. So what questions do you have for me? Patient: Huh, only one, I mean, huh, what are we going to do about this pain I’m feeling? Are we going to do what we’re doing? What we’ve been doing? Doctor: Yeah. I, I’m, I’m thinking we need to change. Huh, you know, get you off these pills and maybe go to chemotherapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Huh, chemotherapy’s got about a one in two chance of helping the pain. Huh, we could always radiate your bones if the pain doesn’t get better with the chemo. Huh, but I’d like to give you something that goes everywhere the cancer cells are, huh, so that, huh, huh, it’s a different approach than what we’ve done. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Huh, so normally what you would end up doing is stopping the four pills. You can stop that. The prednisone you would stay on because we need it for the chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, I think last time we talked a little bit about we have one clinical trial where we are giving men chemotherapy. Huh, that’s the standard. Huh, and then we, huh, ask men to participate and also getting vitamin C. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That’s the experimental part. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: And if that happens, what if all of a sudden he spikes a fever and it happens at night, uh - Doctor: Right, yeah, yeah, that’s right. No, one-eight hundred _____. That is like a twenty-four-hour line. Family Member: Right. Doctor: You can do it yourself, but then you’re flustered. It’s a little bit complicated, - Family Member: Yes, yes. Doctor: So that’s why I prefer; you know I tell people - Patient: Right, yes. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: to just you may want use that one-eight hundred number. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: It’s easier. It takes away the fact of you having to follow the instructions. Family Member: All right. Doctor: And that is on my card if you really want to use that.

Patient: Right. Doctor: and go through that. Family Member: So tomorrow at ten o’clock even if he has, he’s going to see the urologist, should we send you or will you be in touch with them or how? Doctor: We’ve been getting the notes from whoever you see. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: My sense is you guys are great communicators, that you know you have the catheters out, the catheter is not out. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And those are all sorts of things that again that again you’re going to probably need a face-to-face visit with D___ as you come back and so that will be also the time to update you as well. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And again, Dr. ___ was going to want to see you today because he enjoys working with you as well – Patient: Good.

Patient: Don’t do that in the morning, do it – do it at… Doctor: Right. Patient: …dinner or don’t it at dinner. Doctor: When was the last time you saw the integrative medicine folks at B_____? Patient: Ahhh a year ago. Doctor: Okay. I mean it wouldn’t hurt to go back. Now obviously… Patient: Yeah but I want your opinion. Doctor: No no, I’m I’m happy to do that. As we move on to other drugs though… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …we will have to reevaluate that… Patient: That’s fine. Doctor: Because there’s interactions potential. Okay. Patient: Right. That’s why –

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I know, I’m sorry. Patient: And you would recommend that at least at a minimum? Doctor: Well, you know there’s two ways to approach this. We could wait until you really are in trouble. And in trouble would mean you have a fever, you have no white cells, you better come in to the hospital, you need antibiotics. Patient: Yeah I don’t know (stammering) Doctor: But you’ve already demonstrated that your cells go down. You know you weren’t doing great. I just think we’re asking for trouble. So I’ve tried to explain that and they’re like is it a fever with no white cells. That’s all the understand. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I know (sighs) Patient: Because I don’t mind making a phone call either but probably me stay out or what do you think? Doctor: Yeah it’s gonna be all how we code and get them… Patient: Yeah okay. Family Member: So at this point anyway now that we’re in here now okay this is… Doctor: This is it.
